title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by acknowledging the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes and recognizing them as an Indian tribe since 1885. The Lumbee Indians have been recognized by the State of North Carolina since 1885 and by the Congress of the United States in 1956. However, they have been denied the benefits and privileges of federally recognized tribes. The Congress now acknowledges the Lumbee Tribe's entitlement to full Federal recognition and the accompanying benefits. The Lumbee Tribe is entitled to full Federal recognition and benefits. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members. Any group of Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties, North Carolina, not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe and its members are eligible for all services and benefits provided to Indians. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members, including those residing in specific counties, are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. The Secretary of the Interior will verify a tribal roll, and develop a budget for services in consultation with the tribe. Upon verification of a tribal roll, the Secretaries of the Interior and Health and Human Services will collaborate with the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina to determine needs and budget for eligible services. The tribal roll defines the service population for federal services, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. The tribal roll in effect on the date of enactment shall define the service population of the tribe, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. Fee lands to be conveyed to the United States for trust shall be treated as 'on-reservation' trust acquisitions if located within Robeson County, North Carolina. The State of North Carolina shall exercise jurisdiction over. The Secretary of the Interior will treat lands held in trust as 'on-reservation' acquisitions if located in Robeson County, North Carolina. North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the Lumbee Tribe or any dependent Indian community. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers from North Carolina on behalf of the United States. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers from North Carolina on behalf of the United States for the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina or any dependent Indian community. Such transfers may not take effect until 2 years after the agreement. This subsection does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized to carry out this Act.
